g.text: Early in the days it was noticed that empty fullerenes would not rotate as freely if they were
captured in non-covalent complexes as co-crystals.
This way a precise molecular structure
of many fullerenes got to be known with a little to no disorder.
has become a de facto standard for X-ray diffraction studies.
, it turns out that not only has the cage been subdued to order by the presence
of Me(OEP), but also the inner nitride clusters.
It was also found that the orientation of the
N cluster is very sensitive to its exact composition – be it monoionic Sc
N system with Ln = La, Ce, Gd, Tb, Er, or Dy.
low barrier of inner rotation for the M
N clusters, this is a remarkable observation of great
importance in EMF chemistry. Although the ordering effect has already been known for
years, it would be fair to say that its origin is still not well understood. However, it would be
of great use to know the exact energy scale of the effect and if it has a local or cooperative
nature to strategize the search for and design of EMF materials as the ability to form ordered
In this communication, we explore the influence of the interaction between M
Ni(OEP) on the orientation of the endohedral cluster by comprehensive computational
studies. To study the EMF–Ni(OEP) interaction in different environments, we design two
experimental crystal settings taken from ref.
·Ni(OEP) molecular complexes. Since the ionic radius
of Y is close to those of a set lanthanides (Tb, Dy, Ho, etc.), the results obtained in this work
are representative of a larger group of MSc2N@C
those with magnetic lanthanide atoms. Computations were done using the VASP5.0 code at
the PBE-D3/PAW level of theory with a plane-wave basis cut-off of 400 eV consistent with
The endohedral cluster in the isolated M
small energy differences. Obviously, the interaction of the EMF molecule with Ni(OEP)
changes this situation, else the ordering effect would not be observed experimentally. In
other words, the potential energy surface (PES) for the cluster inside the cage becomes more
prolific when it interacts with Ni(OEP) with the appearance of pronounced orientational
minima. But since EMF–Ni(OEP) interactions are non-bonded, the energetic effect on the
endohedral cluster cannot be very strong. To make the theoretical depiction of the systems
complete and consistent, it is necessary to ensure that all energy minima corresponding to
the different orientations of the cluster inside the fullerene are found. It would be insufficient
to optimize one particular structure with an arbitrary orientation of the endohedral cluster.
As illustrated schematically in Fig. 1b, for the complex PES as a function of the order
, with multiple energy minima, a single optimization will most probably proceed
into the closest energy minimum in the configurational space (Fig. 1b, the green dot and
Each system was optimized to a residual force of 0.005 Å eV
. All optimizations for crystal and molecular systems were performed
-point. The molecular systems were put in a cubic unit cell with a side of 25 Å, which ensures no impact due to interactions
with periodic images. The results were analyzed and visualized with in-house Python scripts.
Phys Chem Chem Phys. Author manuscript; available in PMC 2019 November 08.
